Dear Mr. Sebastian:
Attached is the Original Licensing Study Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
established violations, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, an original license will be issued. If you fail
to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Responsive Deployment Children’s Shelter is located on the campus of STARR
Commonwealth in Albion. The facility consists of 13 buildings, which includes 9
cottages which will house youth, 1 educational/administrative building, 1
recreation center, 1 administrative/medical unit building which will house youth
and a mason/supply building. Upon entering the campus down the main drive,
you'll come to a dead end. To the left is the road leading to all the cottages, the
school building, and the supply center. To the right is the road leading to the
administrative/medical unit and the recreation center.
The administrative/medical unit building is called Mary Katherine. One entrance to
the Mary Katherine building leads to all the administrative offices and a
conference room. The other entrance to the Mary Katherine building leads to the
intake area, which contains a lobby and some offices. It also contains two
proposed intake units (Towsley Unit & Kresge Unit), which can each
accommodate up to 15 youth (30 total). One unit will be dedicated for female
youth and the other unit will be dedicated for male youth. In each unit there is a
recreational/game area, lockers for youth's personal items, bedrooms, a dining
table, a staff office, community bathroom/showers, and a laundry room. Mary
Katherine has a total of 10 bedrooms; 5 bedrooms on each unit. Each bedroom
has 2-3 beds/bunk beds. Behind the intake units is a medical area which includes
2 exam rooms, storage, and a medical office. This is where over-the-counter
medications and other medical supplies will be kept, and routine medical exams
5

will be conducted. The main kitchen is also located in the Mary Katherine building.
This is where all the food for the entire campus will be prepared on a 5-week
rotating menu. Once the food is prepared, it will be transported to each of the
cottages for everyone to partake in a family-style dinner.
The 9 cottages are named Ceeley, Kutshe, Kresge, Herrick, Flynn, Oliver, Kindel,
Allen and Besser. The first five cottages are proposed to accommodate female
youth and the last four cottages are proposed to accommodate male youth. There
will not be any co-ed cottages on campus. However, each of the cottages may
change their proposed gender accommodations based on the needs of the
children being placed (i.e. if ORR refers more males than females or vice-versa).
Each of the 9 cottages is an individual, single floor home, and are almost identical
in their arrangement. Each cottage has 6 bedrooms. Bedrooms have
beds/bunkbeds that can accommodate 2-3 youths depending on square footage,
but the total number of youths in each cottage will not exceed 14. Each cottage
has a staff office, storage closet, closet for chemical storage, living room, dining
room, lockers, laundry area, community showers/bathrooms and a
game/recreational room. Each cottage also has a kitchen; however, the kitchen
will not be utilized for preparing food as the food will be brought to each cottage
from the main kitchen in the Mary Katherine building. Each bedroom is set up with
wood framed beds or bunkbeds, mattresses, appropriate bedding, desks, and
chairs. The 13 personal lockers in the home are located as you enter the cottage
and are available for youths’ personal inventory and property. None of the
bedrooms in the cottages have doors, so to maintain privacy, all youth will be
required to change their clothes in the bathroom. Only one youth at a time will be
allowed to be in the shower and/or use the restroom. Each of the bedrooms has
windows, but not all windows open. The windows that open have alarms on them.
Each of the cottages also has a shared basketball court and outdoor picnic tables
for outdoor activities.
The Montcalm School Klare Building is located between the cottages and the
Mary Katherine building. This building will contain all the clinician offices and case
management offices, a call center for the youth to speak with their families, a
conference room, 5-6 classrooms, a staff lounge, a warehouse with shelves for an
overflow of youth belongings, a computer lab, and a cafeteria. Youth will receive
their education on-site and there will be no more than 30 youth per classroom.
The Towsley Center for Recreation is down a small road from the Mary Katherine
Building. The Towsley Center has a large gym with basketball hoops, volleyball,
racquetball, etc. Down the hall from the gym is a large weight room. There are
locker rooms for males and females located within the Towsley Center as well.
There is also a large indoor pool located in the building; however, the facility will
not be utilizing the pool area, and it will always remain locked. Outside of the
6

Towsley Center is a large athletic track, which can also be used for recreational
activities.
An Environmental Health Inspection completed on 12/14/2023 resulted in an "A"
rating.
Sheridan Township approved the facility to be zoned for the purpose of a CCI on
2/14/24. The facility has working cameras in all the main living areas of each of
the buildings, but not in the bedrooms or bathrooms. The cameras have access to
a live stream of those areas and recordings are kept for up to 30 days. There will
be a security monitor watching the live feed videos 24/7/365, but this will not
replace required supervision or ratio requirements. This is meant to be an added
level of safety and security for the campus. The area surrounding the cottages
and buildings the agency is using has an 8-foot welded-wire fence for safety and
security. The security monitor will be doing regular perimeter checks around
campus to ensure safety.
Bureau of Fire Services provided a plan review approval for Allen and Kindel
cottages. Bureau of Fire Services provided an approved final inspection report
dated 3/21/24 for Allen and Kindel cottages. Responsive Deployment continues to
work on bringing the remaining buildings into compliance with fire safety rules.
B. Program Description
Responsive Deployment Children's Shelter is a program designed to offer a
temporary, safe placement for Unaccompanied Children who are under the care
of the Office of Refugee and Resettlement (ORR). The facility is being licensed for
a capacity of 156 male and female youth, ages 10-17. None of the cottages will be
co-ed. However, each of the cottages may change their proposed gender
accommodations based on the needs of the children being placed (i.e. if ORR
refers more males than females or vice-versa). The facility could serve youth from
various parts of the world, but the most common countries include Central
America, South America, and Mexico. The staff-to-resident ratio is 1:8 during
awake hours and 1:16 during sleeping hours.
Youth will stay in the shelter until an identified next placement is found, which
could include, but is not limited to, renunciation with a family/sponsor, a more
appropriate shelter setting, long-term foster care, or repatriation. The average
length of stay for youth will be approximately 30-45 days but could be extended if
it takes longer to find a placement.
During a youth's stay, they will be assigned a bilingual case manager who
provides intensive case management services. The youth will meet with their case
manager a minimum of once per week. During meetings, the case manager will
assess and determine what types of supports and interventions are needed.
Services offered include case management services, unification services, medical
services, mental health services (1 individual and 2 group counseling sessions per
7

week), educational services, recreational services, community outings, and
interpretation services. The facility uses the Managing Aggressive Behavior
model for de-escalation and restraints. Crisis intervention and support is available
24/7.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at
the time specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee
a nd which are less than 12 months old.
Four of twelve new employee files reviewed did not have three dated references
within 12 months prior to hire. Two employees only had two references completed
prior to hire. A third employee's professional reference was not dated and her
PSA reference was completed after she was hired. A fourth employee's
professional reference was not dated.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at
the time specified in this rule:
(f) A record of any convictions other than minor
traffic violations from either of the following entities:
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police or the
equivalent state law enforcement agency, Canadian
province, or other country where the person usually
r esides or has resided in the previous 5 years.
One of twelve new employee files reviewed had a criminal background check
completed on 1/11/24, which was one day after the employee's hire date.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at
the time specified in this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of
human services, the equivalent state or Canadian
provincial agency, or equivalent agency in the country
where the person usually resides, that the person has
8

not been determined to be a perpetrator of child abuse
or child neglect. The documentation shall be completed
not more than 30 days prior to the start of employment
and every 12 months thereafter.
Three of twelve new employee files reviewed did not have a central registry check
completed within 30 days prior to hire. Two employees were hired 1/10/24, but
their central registry checks weren't completed until 1/30/24. A third employee
lived in two different states in the last 5 years. One check was completed over 12
months prior to hire and the other was completed 1 day after hire.
CCI Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and
volunteers
(1) The licensee shall document, prior to employment,
that each employee and volunteer who has contact with
residents 4 or more hours per week for more than 2
consecutive weeks is free from communicable
tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable tuberculosis
shall be verified within the 1 year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the
last verification or prior to the expiration of the current
verification.
Four of twelve new employee files reviewed did not have a TB test completed
within 1 year prior to employment.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Responsive Deployment requested a variance which was approved on
March 21, 2024. The variance was granted to allow a license to be issued
with a capacity of 156 youth, however only 28 beds (Allen and Kindel
cottages) at the time of licensure are in full compliance with Part 5 of the
rules. The remaining 128 beds (Mary Katherine, Besser, Ceeley, Flynn,
Herrick, Kresge, Oliver, and Kutsche) will gradually come into compliance
as the agency plans to have the remaining 8 buildings/cottages, come into
full compliance by June 3, 2024.
During the time of this variance, youth can only initially be placed in the 28
beds located in Allen and Kindel cottages. Mary Katherine, Besser, Ceeley,
Flynn, Herrick, Kresge, Oliver, and Kutsche cottages will not have youth
placed until all of the following is met:
• All deficiencies for fire safety rules come into compliance.
• The Bureau of Fire Services have approved the specific
cottage/building as documented in the plan review report.
• The Bureau of Fire Services have approved the specific
cottage/building as documented in the inspection report.
9

• Division of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) has approved in writing
the cottage/building can begin accepting youth.
Due to established rule violations, a written corrective action plan is required. Upon
approval of the corrective action plan, a six-month original license is recommended.
